rev.comment: /* Deaths */ Not a blogger (Sorry for the confusion)

[[File:Martyrs memorial in Tahrir.jpg|thumb|A memorial in Tahrir Square made by the demonstrators in honour of those who died during the protests, regarded as ''[[Shahid|shuhada']]'' Ø´ÙØ¯Ø§Ø¡ â "martyrs" â in Egyptian parlance. [[File:Sally Zahran.png|thumb|Sally Zahran, a female blogger who was beaten to death during Tahrir square demonstrations, and whose death was the target of Mubarak regime propaganda. [[NASA]] announced plans to write her name on a rocket, as part of a tradition of the American space organization's Jet Propulsion Laboratory to engrave the names of notable people on spacecraft at the request of NASA staff members or US citizens. âThis is the least we could do for Egypt's youth and the revolutionaries. This step represents the transfer of the dreams of Egyptian young people from a small stretch of earth to the enormous expanse of space,â said NASA researcher Essam Mohamed Haji.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/314995 | publisher=Al-Masry Al-Youm | work=NASA to honor Tahrir Square martyr by putting name on spacecraft | date=February 10, 2011 | accessdate=April 18, 2011 | author=Zalat, Ali}}</ref>]].
+
[[File:Sally Zahran.png|thumb|Sally Zahran, a female protester who was beaten to death during Tahrir square demonstrations, and whose death was the target of Mubarak regime propaganda. [[NASA]] announced plans to write her name on a rocket, as part of a tradition of the American space organization's Jet Propulsion Laboratory to engrave the names of notable people on spacecraft at the request of NASA staff members or US citizens. "This is the least we could do for Egypt's youth and the revolutionaries. This step represents the transfer of the dreams of Egyptian young people from a small stretch of earth to the enormous expanse of space" said NASA researcher Essam Mohamed Haji.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/314995 | publisher=Al-Masry Al-Youm | work=NASA to honor Tahrir Square martyr by putting name on spacecraft | date=February 10, 2011 | accessdate=April 18, 2011 | author=Zalat, Ali}}</ref>]].
Leading up to the protests, at least six cases of [[self-immolation]] were reported, including a man arrested while trying to set himself on fire in downtown Cairo.<ref name="Self-Immolation Spreads Across the Mideast">{{cite web|author=Rosenberg, David|url=http://www.themedialine.org/news/news_detail.asp?NewsID=31194|title=Self-Immolation Spreads Across the Mideast, Inspiring Protest, Controversy|work=[[The Media Line]]|date=24 January 2011|accessdate=25 January 2011}}</ref> These cases were inspired by, and began exactly one month after, the acts of self-immolation in Tunisia triggering the [[2010â2011 Tunisian uprising]]. Six instances have been reported, including acts by Abdou Abdel-Moneim Jaafar,<ref name="Abdou Abdel-Moneim">{{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.net/NR/exeres/7F5D64C8-241F-4F34-B36A-4F259CBF3371.htm?GoogleStatID=20|title=ÙØµØ±Ù ÙØ­Ø±Ù ÙÙØ³Ù Ø£ÙØ§Ù Ø§ÙØ¨Ø±ÙÙØ§Ù|language=[[Arabic language|Arabic]]|work=[[Al Jazeera]]|date=17 January 2011|accessdate=25 January 2011}}</ref> Mohammed Farouk Hassan,<ref name="Mohammed Farouk Hassan">{{cite news|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/idUSTRE70H3L720110118|title=Egyptians Set Themselves Ablaze After Tunisia Unrest|author=Zayed, Dina|date=18 January 2011|work=[[Reuters]]|accessdate=25 January 2011}}</ref> Mohammed Ashour Sorour,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.elosboaonline.com/show.asp?id=20522&vnum=fesal&page=mahalyat|title=ÙÙØ¸Ù Ø¨Ù'ÙØµØ± ÙÙØ·ÙØ±Ø§Ù' ÙÙØ¯Ø¯ Ø¨Ø­Ø±Ù ÙÙØ³Ù Ø£ÙØ§Ù ÙÙØ§Ø¨Ø© Ø§ÙØµØ­ÙÙÙÙ|language=[[Arabic language|Arabic]]|date=18 January 2011|work=[[El-Aosboa]] (newspaper)|accessdate=25 January 2011}}</ref> and Ahmed Hashim al-Sayyed who later died from his injuries.<ref name="Ahmed Hashim El-Sayyid2">{{cite web
